subject: RE: [junit] Identify name of the TestCase

Hi,

After much of the work, am able to make a customised test frame using jUnit,
bypassing the test runner. Just implemented the TestListener and the job is
done. Don't know if there are other methods to do that, but by-passing the
testrunner makes us to not see the ouput on the console and everything is
logged without any output on the console.

Am still extending the thing and hope it will be in shape soon :-)

Regards
Vipul

-----Original Message-----
From: Katie Gerg [mailto:kgerg@...]
Sent: Wednesday, April 16, 2003 7:34 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Identify name of the TestCase


I'll have to take a look at the TestRunner again.  I looked at the textui
classes, ResultPrinter and TestRunner.  ResultPrinter implements
TestListener, The TestRunner class extends BaseTestRunner, which in turn
implements TestListener - my head then exploded - just kidding.    At any
rate, I just by passed the runner and had the listener keep track of all the
results, names, error/failure descriptions and detailed test case
description in an object.

I know this is a hack so I intend to go back and look at it later.


  -----Original Message-----
  From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
  Sent: Tuesday, April 15, 2003 05:18 PM
  To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: RE: [junit] Identify name of the TestCase


  It sounds like all you needed was to register a TestListener so that, for
each test, you could collect its name. What you do with those names
afterward is totally up to the individual.

  Writing the TestListener is nothing. Attaching the TestListener to the
TestRunner may take some work. I've never actually done it. I would have to
look at the code.

  I suppose you could have written your own TestRunner that instantiates the
text runner, adds the listener, asks the text runner to run the tests, then
processes the results from your listener. Is this what you did? If not, then
what did you do?

  Thanks.

  >So said Katie Gerg on 4/15/2003 --------------------
  >I'm embarrassed to post it because I'm really serious when I say I hacked
  >it.  I have to get a suite of automated tests done by the end of this
week
  >so I did it without completely understanding junit but I knew what I
wanted
  >to get out of it.  The tests I need to run are highly specialized
(they're
  >the same with different inputs).
  >
  >I wanted a list of test cases so I know what test cases I've run against
a
  >build (hey I'm a qa person, I have to know what's in there not only what
  >failed - esp. from a test coverage perspective).  I also wanted it in a
  >format anyone could easily view, so I store the test results in a vector
  >that I dump out in an html format at the end (the location is hardcoded
for
  >now but it'll eventually come from a property file).
  >
  >Anyway, I confronted the same issue you had with the listener so I made
my
  >own testresult object that the testcase class initializes and the
listener
  >grabs it from it.
  >
  >I'll send it to you but I don't think it fits into the junit way of
  >thinking.
  >
  >
  >
  >
  >  -----Original Message-----
  >  From: Jesse Marlin [mailto:jlm@...]
  >  Sent: Tuesday, April 15, 2003 03:36 PM
  >  To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  >  Subject: RE: [junit] Identify name of the TestCase
  >
  >
  >  J. B. Rainsberger writes:
  >  > >So said Katie Gerg on 4/14/2003 --------------------
  >  > >I wanted a list of all the test cases I've run so I made a listener
  >(and
  >  > >did
  >  > >some other probably not very kosher tactics).
  >  >
  >  > It's kosher if:
  >  >
  >  > * It works.
  >  > * You refactored.
  >  >
  >  > If you didn't refactor, then do it now! :)
  >  >
  >  > >I can email it to you personally if you'd like maybe you could come
up
  >with
  >  > >something better :-).
  >  >
  >  > Why not post it to the group? Upload it to the file section. Get your
  >name in lights.
  >
  >  I agree.  I am having a difficult time finding substantive examples,
  >  and am currently struggling with TestListener.  I don't understand
  >  the relationship between a TestResult and a TestCase.  TestResult
  >  actually has the addListener method which I need, but I am not sure
  >  what to do to get a TestResult from the context of a TestCase.
  >
